author: lefterisjp
content:
Hey guys congrats on the amazing milestone today. I come with a probably super nooby question but just would like to confirm.

In order for a user to stake she needs 32 ETH. Only multiples of this can be staked. And for each multiple a different validator needs to run?

author: ryg9705
content: <@593179283061735475> You can run 1000 or more validator keys on one validator client.

author: ryg9705
content: And yes you can only stake multiples.

author: lefterisjp
content: so same client multiple keys. Does it affect performance, the more validator keys you run? Or probably negligible?

author: ryg9705
content: In terms of CPU/RAM usage it is exactly the same. I run 1100 validators on the test net and started with 10 and then 100.

author: ryg9705
content: Or hardly a difference is probably more correct.

author: ajsutton
content: There is a noticeable difference in network bandwidth and CPU usage between running 1 validator and 64.  After 64 you're already subscribed to every attestation subnet so there's very little extra cost.

author: ryg9705
content: Bandwidth usage increased

author: ryg9705
content: With my validator count I was pushing around 350-400 GB per month.

author: lefterisjp
content: I see. Thanks guys. This is useful. Trying to understand the hardware requirements a bit more.

author: ryg9705
content: <@!593179283061735475> If you want to prioritize one thing in a node it's RAM. Technically you can run a node with as little as 4 GB RAM and it will power insane numbers of validators but I would not go below 16 for mainnet.

author: ryg9705
content: Many weak nodes got killed during non finality when RAM usage increased. My client was using around 10 GB RAM during the network troubles. You'd also need to run a geth node for ETH1 data. On testnet I used infura but mainnet should be a dedicated eth1 node.
